Hamirpur

Hamirpur sits in the lower hills of west-central Himachal. The land is all ridges and small valleys, with the Beas River on the north and many khads (seasonal streams) like Kunah and Maan running through. What sets Hamirpur apart is its connectivity and character, roads link nearly every settlement, schools are found in abundance, and the district is proudly known for producing both soldiers and scholars. (By area, it’s the smallest district in Himachal.)

Our Hidden Favourites

  • Sujanpur Chaugan at sunrise — A huge green ground by the Beas; best for early walks and kite flying before the crowd.
  • Narbadeshwar Temple murals (Sujanpur) — 200-year-old wall paintings; go with a local priest/guide to spot the details.
  • Nadaun river ghats — Quiet evening spot; anglers try for mahseer, others just sit by the Beas and sip tea.
  • Markandeya Kund (near Dera Parol) — A spring by the temple; peaceful, shaded by big trees.
  • Awah Devi ridge — Clear-day 360° views; quick tea at the top shops, sunsets are sharp here.

Towns & Villages

  • Hamirpur (HQ, ~786 m) — Administrative hub with bazaars around Gandhi Chowk. Colleges and coaching centers give it a student feel. Good base to reach anywhere in the district.
  • Sujanpur Tira (515 m) — Historic town on the Beas. Big Chaugan ground, Katoch Palace/Fort ruins on the hill, and painted temples (Narbadeshwar, Murli Manohar, Gauri Shankar). Holi fair is the big draw.
  • Nadaun — Small riverside town tied to the Battle of Nadaun. Gurudwara Patshahi Dasvin faces the Beas. Known for mahseer angling and seasonal rafting down to Dehra (Kangra side).
  • Barsar belt (Barsar–Galore–Bhota) — Market ridge in the south. Gateway towards Baba Balak Nath (Deot Sidh) on the Hamirpur–Bilaspur border. Galore has hill temples like Chaniari Devi; Bhota is a highway halt with a historic gurudwara.
  • Bhoranj side — Farming villages and a government college. Good for simple village stays and ridge walks.
  • Tauni Devi / Ladraur / Dera Parol / Lambloo — Typical hill villages with terraces, pine edges, and local devta shrines. Tauni Devi Temple has a popular summer fair; Ladraur hosts Sair in mid-September; Dera Parol is the stop for Markandeya Ashram.

Culture & Festivals

  • Sujanpur Holi: Week-long fair on the Chaugan with colors, folk shows, sports.
  • Hamir Utsav (Nov, Hamirpur town): District day with cultural teams and stalls.
  • Baba Balak Nath Fair (Deot Sidh, Mar–Apr): Continuous kirtan and long queues.
  • Temple melas: Gasota, Tauni Devi, Awah Devi, Markanda: village fairs like Ladraur Sair (mid-Sep).
  • Seasonal: Chet/Dholru: (spring new year), Sair (post-monsoon thanksgiving).

Education & Youth

  • Colleges & institutes: NIT Hamirpur, Himachal Pradesh Technical University, Govt Medical College, College of Horticulture & Forestry (Neri), IHM, polytechnic and many degree colleges.
  • Identity: Called Veerbhumi—many youths serve in the Army, Air Force, Navy; recruitment rallies see big turnout.
  • Literacy: Highest in the state. Coaching culture is strong; student cafés and hostels give Hamirpur town a youthful rhythm.

Our Stories

Exploring the majestic peaks of the Himalayas, capturing breathtaking moments.

Immersing ourselves in the rich culture and vibrant traditions of Himachal Pradesh.

Food & Markets

  • Dham (festival feast): rice with madra (chickpea/rajma in yogurt), sepu badi, khatta, and meetha.
  • Local favourites: siddu, babru, maahni, teliye mah; in winter, makki di roti & sarson da saag influence from the plains.
  • Where to eat: small bhojanalayas in Hamirpur bazaar; tea stalls around Sujanpur/Nadaun; highway dhabas near Barsar–Bhota. Ask locals for the current best siddu spot—these change.
  • Local Produce: mangoes and loquats in lower belts.

Getting There & Around

  • Roads: Very dense network; HRTC buses and shared cabs connect all blocks.
  • Nearest airport: Gaggal (Kangra) ~80–85 km.
  • Nearest railheads: Una / Amb ~70–80 km.
  • Best season to visit: Oct–Mar (clear, pleasant) and Feb–Apr (with Holi).
  • Monsoon note: Jul–Sep—roads can be slippery; rafting season depends on flow.

History in Short

Part of the old Kangra (Trigarta) region. Named after Raja Hamir Chand (Katoch). Raja Sansar Chand later made Sujanpur his base; the palace ruins and painted temples remain. Guru Gobind Singh camped at Nadaun after the battle; the gurudwara marks it.



Faith & Places

  • Baba Balak Nath (Deot Sidh) — Cave shrine on the Hamirpur–Bilaspur border; men enter the inner cave, women pray from the platform. Peak crowd in Chaitra/Navratri.
  • Gasota Mahadev (near Hamirpur) — Local Shiva temple with Monday rush in season.
  • Awah Devi Temple — On the highest hill; Navratri and an annual fair.
  • Tauni Devi Temple — Early monsoon fair (Asharh).
  • Markandeya (Markanda) Ashram — Spring, small temple, and Baisakhi fair.
  • Gurudwara Nadaun Sahib — Riverscape and langar; quiet, welcoming.
